questions.title: Quick Microplastic Reduction
questions.statement: There are actions you can take (that only take a few seconds) and can help you to reduce your exposure to microplastics drastically.

actionsReceived.name: syntheticheat
actionsReceived.title: Synthetic Heat
actionsReceived.statement: You washed synthetic clothes at a very high temperature. More heat = more microplastics! Add two microplastics.

questions.title: Plants and Microplastics
questions.statement: Plants grow normally despite the presence of microplastics, while algae are affected.

actionsReceived.name: naturaliscool
actionsReceived.title: Natural is Cool
actionsReceived.statement: In your group, cotton and linen are the favorite fabrics. Natural fibres shed fewer airborne microplastics, so you fit right in. Remove 1 microplastic from indoor air.

questions.title: Natural vs Synthetic Clothing Comfort
questions.statement: Most people think that natural clothes are more comfortable than synthetic clothes.

actionsReceived.name: syntheticheat
actionsReceived.title: Synthetic Heat
actionsReceived.statement: You washed synthetic clothes at a very high temperature. More heat = more microplastics! Add two microplastics.

questions.title: Plants and Microplastics
questions.statement: Plants grow normally despite the presence of microplastics, while algae are affected.

questions.title: Microplastics in Human Placenta
questions.statement: Microplastics have been found in the human placenta.

questions.statement: There is no research yet showing health effects of microplastics in humans

actionsReceived.name: tumbledryer
actionsReceived.title: Tumble Dryer
actionsReceived.statement: You dried your laundry with the tumble dryer this week. That releases many microplastic fibres in your indoor air! Add two microplastics.

actionsReceived.name: naturaliscool
actionsReceived.title: Natural is Cool
actionsReceived.statement: In your group, cotton and linen are the favorite fabrics. Natural fibres shed fewer airborne microplastics, so you fit right in. Remove 1 microplastic from indoor air.

actionsReceived.name: tumbledryer
actionsReceived.title: Tumble Dryer
actionsReceived.statement: You dried your laundry with the tumble dryer this week. That releases many microplastic fibres in your indoor air! Add two microplastics.

questions.title: Dutch Laundry Habits
questions.statement: The large majority of Dutch people wash clothes at a low temperature.

questions.title: Global Plastic Recycling
questions.statement: Most global plastic waste is recycled.

actionsReceived.name: fulllaundryload
actionsReceived.title: Full Laundry Load
actionsReceived.statement: You chose to wash a full load of laundry. Less free space = less friction. Keep this card until the next laundry cycle, then add only half the usual microplastics.

actionsReceived.name: houserules
actionsReceived.title: House Rules
actionsReceived.statement: Your housemates agree: let's wash at colder temperatures to release fewer airborne fibres into the house. You stick to the plan. Next time you do laundry, add 1 fewer microplastic to indoor air.

actionsReceived.name: houserules
actionsReceived.title: House Rules
actionsReceived.statement: Your housemates agree: let's wash at colder temperatures to release fewer airborne fibres into the house. You stick to the plan. Next time you do laundry, add 1 fewer microplastic to indoor air.

questions.title: Microplastic Ingestion Sources
questions.statement: The amount of microplastics we ingest depends exclusively on our diet

actionsReceived.name: airdrying
actionsReceived.title: Air-drying
actionsReceived.statement: You air-dried your laundry instead of using a tumble dryer. You prevented a lot of microplastics from getting into the air. Smart move! Keep this card until the next laundry cycle, then add only half the usual microplastics.

questions.title: Single-use Plastics
questions.statement: Most of the world's population wants to get rid of single-use plastics.

questions.title: Microplastic Particle Size
questions.statement: The smallest microplastic particle found by scientists are comparable in thickness to a human hair
